articles.headline: Los Angeles Voters Are in a Foul Mood. Will a New Mayor Change Anything?
articles.snippet: Residents are frustrated over homelessness, crime and rising costs. Two candidates for mayor, Karen Bass and Rick Caruso, say they can turn the tide.
articles.abstract: Residents are frustrated over homelessness, crime and rising costs. Two candidates for mayor, Karen Bass and Rick Caruso, say they can turn the tide.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was Saturday and sunny in the nation’s second most populous city, but the Rev. James McKnight’s mood was grim.

articles.headline: When Does Collaboration Become Collusion?
articles.snippet: Adhering to antitrust regulation while negotiating collective sustainability targets is proving tougher to navigate for some in the fashion industry.
articles.abstract: Adhering to antitrust regulation while negotiating collective sustainability targets is proving tougher to navigate for some in the fashion industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2020, during the earliest and darkest months of the coronavirus pandemic, a group of clothing executives and designers began talking — tentatively — about upending some of the global fashion industry’s hidebound practices.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Paton, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross

articles.headline: Facing a Tide of Criticism, Elon Musk Is Tweeting Through It
articles.snippet: The new owner of Twitter has embarked on a tweeting spree to push back, spar and justify his actions.
articles.abstract: The new owner of Twitter has embarked on a tweeting spree to push back, spar and justify his actions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under pressure and facing a wave of criticism, Elon Musk has increasingly turned to his favorite release valve: Twitter.

articles.headline: Apple Built Its Empire With China. Now Its Foundation Is Showing Cracks.
articles.snippet: Lawmakers’ objections to an obscure Chinese semiconductor company and tough Covid-19 restrictions are hurting Apple’s ability to make new iPhones in China.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers’ objections to an obscure Chinese semiconductor company and tough Covid-19 restrictions are hurting Apple’s ability to make new iPhones in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every September, Apple unveils its latest phones at its futuristic Silicon Valley campus. A few weeks later, tens of millions of its newest handsets, assembled by legions of seasonal workers hired by its suppliers, are shipped from Chinese factories to customers around the world.
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle, Chang Che and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Fueled by Falsehoods, a Michigan Group Is Ready to Challenge the Vote
articles.snippet: In private meetings, activists, lawyers and G.O.P. officials laid out their strategy. “If there is a close election, it’s going to be up to us to fix it,” one said.
articles.abstract: In private meetings, activists, lawyers and G.O.P. officials laid out their strategy. “If there is a close election, it’s going to be up to us to fix it,” one said.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The invitation went out in early July.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Berzon and Ken Bensinger

articles.headline: The World’s Democracies Ask: Why Can’t America Fix Itself?
articles.snippet: Conversations across continents reveal alarm over the United States’ direction, as it slides away from ideals it once pressed other nations to adopt.
articles.abstract: Conversations across continents reveal alarm over the United States’ direction, as it slides away from ideals it once pressed other nations to adopt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lin Wei-hsuan was just a child when he observed his first Taiwanese election almost two decades ago. His parents took him to watch the vote-counting, where volunteers held up each paper ballot, shouting out the choice and marking it on a board for all to see — the huge crowd of citizens inside, and many more watching live on television.
